listWit.witness: London, British Museum Royal 10 A I

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of this text has followed the recommendations of the LombardPress 1.0.0 guidelines for a critical edition.

change.p: File Started for the first time.

div.p:
Nunc ad distinctionem personarum Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 9, c. 1 [n.1], (I, 103, ll. 6). . This is the ninth distinction of this first book in which after the Master determined about divine generation, now he determines about the coeternal generation of the Father and the Son. And he divides this into two parts because he first shows their coeternity wither respect to the intrinsic mode of being, in the second place with respect to the mode of speaking or signifying. The second begins at
hic quaeri potest Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 9, c. 4 [n.1], (I, 106, ll. 3). .

The first is divided into four because in the first place puts forward the distinction of the divine persons, second he considers their equal duration, third he introduces against this the objection of the heretics, fourth he defeats the presumption of the opposition. The second begins at
genitus est enim Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 9, c. 2 [n.1], (I, 103, ll. 15). . The third at
sed contra hoc Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 9, c. 2 [n.2], (I, 103, ll. 18). . The fourth at
sed quaeris Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 9, c. 3 [n.1], (I, 105, ll. 3).

The second principal part is divided into three because first he introduces a disputable opinion, second harmonized the apparent disagreement of the doctors, third he introduces the conclusion that should be held about this matter. The second begins at
dicamus ergo Filium Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 9, c. 4 [n.8/13], (I, 109, ll. 6). . The third at
Sed inquiet haeretics
L leaves a blank here, and the supplied incipit "sed inquiet haereticis" is a likely suggestion of the likely referenced intended by Gracilis.
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 9, c. 5 [n.1], (I, 109, ll. 29). . This is the division of this lecture.
Whether priority of any durative measure is repugnant to a supposite or person of a divine nature?

That not because the Word is the measure of a creature, therefore the Word is not coeternal with the Father. The antecedent is clear and the consequence is proved because equal and proportionate in a measured way to what it measures.

In the second place the divine Word is immense, therefore it is not measured by eternity because it seems to be a contradiction for the immense to be measured. The antecedent is a catholic truth. This is confirmed because the Word is above and beyond eternity, therefore it is not measured by eternity. Elsewhere it is proved in Exodus chapter 3:
Dominus regnabit et ultra Exodus 15:18 .

In the third place, eternity is made, therefore the Word is not eternity, nor is it measured by it. The antecedent is clear through Augustine in 83 questions
where he says:
God is the author of eternity Augustinus, De diversis quaestionibus octoginta tribus, q.23 (CCSL 44A, 27, ll. 11-12) . Again Boethius says that
sicut nunc fluens facit temporis sic nunc stans et permanens facit aeternitatem Boetius, XXX .
In opposition is the claim of the Master of the Sentences in this distinction. Again, in a similar way, in this Trinity there is not prior or posterior, etc.

The first conclusion: though eternally or the duration of eternity in abstract to world outside itself is not a communicable perfection, nevertheless this is an eternal and formal measure of whatever is produced. The first part is because it would follow that a creature would be able to be coeternal with God or that any creature would be produced before some time, but each of these options is false or impossible, therefore. The second part is proved because the properties of measure do not properly suit God with respect to a creature and not only transumptively, therefore. The antecedent is show by Giles, in book two, distinction eight, question three, in part two since the ratio of number fits himself temporally, uniformally, absolutely, and indivisibly. Secondly, because ratio of adequation suits the the creature in two ways, namely through conformity and imitation, therefore it follows that God is causally, formally the measure of any produced being. The first part of the conclusion is confirmed because invariability, immutability, and simultaneity, therefore not eternity. The consequence is clear because these are properties of eternity as will be clear later. And the antecedent is clear because according to Gregory
in that in which a creature is, it has the vicissitude of changeability Gregorius Magnus, Moralia, V, c. 37, 4 .

The first corollary: immensity and eternity of measure do not infer the immensity of the measured nature, against
John of Marchia, in the first question of his Sentences, in his determination in the response of the first argument against the second conclusion . This is clear because the immense God is the formal measure of the creature, and nevertheless the creature is not immense, and as a consequence is not proportionally adequate to him, as he says there.

The second corollary: the ratio of formal eternity is not a denomination of perfection absolutely. This is clear because any such perfection is communicable outside itself to a creature concretely, but eternity is not communicable to a creature, therefore.
From the first corollary and conclusion it follows that any material and divisible nature is measured by an immaterial and indivisible measure in some mode and not adequately.

The third corollary: though eternity as such is not a perfection as if absolutely denotively, nevertheless it is a mode of perfection in identity, really, and entitatively. The first part is clear through the
second corollary Vide supra . The second is proved because eternity is essentially the eternal God.

The second conclusion: just as the highest goodness is its own supersimple nature, so it is its own eternity and every measure of it. This is proved through Anselm Monologion 24 where he says
it stands that the highest substance exists without a beginning and an end, nor does it have a present, past, or future Anselmus, Monologion, 24,(I, 42, ll. 11-12). .

Item
Alexander in the book On the memory of difficult things, proposition 52 says
tempus rem a suo principio distare facit aeternitas vero rem suae causae continuat[?] et coniungit in aeternitate non est pars neque prius aut posterius Alexander, XXX .

Again proposition 44 says that
nullum immutabile mensuratur
mensura successiva aut succedente sed aeterna Alexander de Alexandria, De memoria rerum difficilium, prop. 44
.

The first corollary: the measure of any divine operation or causality is an every present and indivisible instant of eternity. This is clear because God is his own operation taken nominally and actively, therefore. This is confirmed because both God and creature are measured by eternity, and as a consequence by this instant because they are precisely the same thing.

The second corollary: a plurality of gods is as repugnant to divinity as multiplicity of signs is repugnant to eternity. therefore any measure of it is totally adequate to it. But any sign or instant of eternity is a proper measure of it, therefore any such thing is simple and not multiple. And I understand through equal measure with God lasting supersimple permanence and being independent and without a beginning.

Third corollary: just as eternity is a measure intrinsecly exlcuding a plurality of signs, so an instant of eternity is including contentively every durative succession. The first part is opposed to Scotum in many places which is proved thus because otherwise the entire Trinity will be more multiple than its signification, which is false and against the
second corollary Vide supra . Again the sign would be simpler than its eternity, which is false.

The second part is against Hugolino which is proved because the instant of eternity is adequately this instant of eternity, therefore any instant of eternity is a precontentive instant of eternity contentively including this and inclusively containing this. But eternity precontains and includes every successive durative pause both real and imaginative, therefore.

Third conclusion: the generation of the eternal word or to generate eternally in an instant of eternity is considered to be measured. This is clear through Damescenus, in book one, chapter 8
divine generation is without beginning and eternal, existing as a work of nature Ioannes Damascenus, De fide orthodoxa, I, 8, (PG 94, 813: Buytaert 32, 77-80) . Again this is proved by reason because this generation is invariable, incorruptible, simultaneous without succession, but these are properties of eternity, therefore. The first part of the antecedent is clear, and the second is through Augustine III De Trinitate, chapter three who says that
God is true eternity Augustinus, De Trinitate, III . Again in IV De Trinitate, chapter 19
his true eternity is incommunicabile Augustinus, De Trinitate, IV, 18, 24
To the same speaks Giles, in distinction 8 of book 1, the second part, question two where he posits these properties inforam

The first corollary: it is not the case that the Word is able to be called for any sign and in that instant this is not produced through generation, which is contrary to
Scotus, in distinction 22 of book 1, in the second question Scotus, Ordinatio, I, d. 22, q. 2 . This is proved because if in some sign the Father were able to generate the Son and for that instant he would not generate him, it follows that generation would not be measured by an instant lacking a beginning. The consequent is false through what has been said. The consequence is clear because the first sign in which a first person is habitually fecund would precede the generation of the Son, and as a consequence for that instant there will be a preceding negation of the word, which is false.

The second corollary: for any sign the Father generates an only begotten, the Son spirates the Holy Spirit with the same sign, contra Scotus,
where it is proved aboved in the sign the first sign of the origin in which the Fater is fecund and the Son not according to him and is this sign a and according to the sing in which the Son is fecund and is b, then thus a has a separate negation of fecundity of the Son, therefore in a the Son is not fecund, and a is before b, therefore before the Son is not fecund to prior to the point when he is fecund. The consequence is clear because a is prior, b is posterior, otherwise a would not be first and b second as he says. But this consequent is false because then the Son would begin to be fecund and he would not be fecund without beginning against what has been said, therefore the corollary is true.

The third corollary is the affirmative title of the question which is proved by
Lord Alphonsus, in distinction one Alphonsus Vargas, I, d. 1, xxx , see there. This is confirmed because in the divine there is not some priority besides some origin not in any place. I do not intend to deny through what has been said in this question because I speak only about the measurative priority against Scotus's way of speaking who thinks that in
an instant of eternity there are three signs of the origin. In the first are all the essentials, namely knowledge, wisdom, goodness, etc. In the second the Father generates the Son. In the third he spirates the Holy Spirit and he says consequently that the Father spirates the Holy Spirit from an origin prior to that of the Son, see
Alphonsus, in distinction 9 of the first book Alphonsus Vargas, I, d. 9, ?? . The responsive corollary Alphonsus proves thus, virtually in the Son and to any divine person for any sign of the origin or nature it is repugnatn not to be, therefore also to be posterior, therefore no person is prior to the other. The antecedent is clear because it is necessary in the highest degree. And the consequence is clear because, for if for some some sign one person is prior, then another is posterior. But therefore in that sign the Son has being or not. If yes, then in that instant the Father is not prior to him. If not, then the Son has being after non being and thus is produced from non being to being. The consequence is clear because in the second he has being, indeed it follows that no being is not repugnant to the Son which in opposition to the antecedent.

div.head: Obiectiones et Responsiones
div.p:
Contra prima conclusionem: Deus non est eiusdem generis cum creatis ergo earum non est mensura. haec
consequentia consequentiam
patet per
Philosophum X Metaphysicae
dicentem
mensura debet esse unigena, Augustinus, Metaphysicae, X
id est, unius generis cum mensurato. Secundo Deus non est creaturae proportionalis. Item non est replicabilis. Item quantitas non convenit Deo vel aeternitati, sed istae sunt mensurae proprietates, ergo.

Contra secundam conclusionem et corollaria eius: si mensura aeterna foret propria cuilibet operationi divinae intrinsece, sequitur quod facere divinum esset aeternum. Consequens non vietur verum, sed apparet consequentia quia tum velle divinum sit aeternum et divinum velle sit facere, sequitur divinum facere esse aeternum, et sic ab eo aeterno omnia facta fuissent.

Secundo, sequitur quod duo contradictoria in instanti aeternitatis sint simul simul vera consequens est falsum consequentia probatur quia deus non vult modo christum pati et illud non velle est entium et voluit christum pati ergo illud velle fuit aeternum et sic in eodem instanti illud voluit et noluit seu non voluit quae sunt contradictoria.
Tertio, si aeque praesens velle futurum esse esset et praeteritum esse praeteritum, sequitur quod aeque necessariam esset unum sicut reliquum. Consequens est falsum.

Quarto, contra corollaria: omne illud quod dicit indivisibile esse indivisibiliter est simplicius illo quod dicit indivisibile esse et non indivisibiliter, sed signum vel instans aeternitatis dicit indivisibile indivisibiliter aeternitas vero indivisibile, sed non indivisibiliter, ergo etc.

Quinto, contra secundum et tertium corollarium videtur esse illud Iohannis 16 ubi dicitur de spiritu
quaecumque audiet loquetur, Ioannes 16:13
sed certum est quod illud futurum non potest referri nisi ad aliquod signum aeternale et sic erunt plura in aeternitate signa. Item Iohannis 12
clarifica me pater claritate Ioannes 17:5
quam habui priusquam mundus fient. Item contra conclusionem est dictum
Boetii
augustini boetii
superius allegati quia si aeternitas enfecta[?], sequitur quod non sit Deus. Item auctoritas Augustini.
Contra tertiam conclusionem est ratio facta in oppositum quia verbum divinum, etc.

Secundo, per illud
Exodi 3o.
Dominus regnabit et ultra Exodus 15:18

Tertio, generatio passiva et Filius habet principium, ergo eius duratio habet principium. Patet consequentia quia sunt idem. Antecedens patet per Augustinum V De Trinitate 14 dicentem
Pater est principium Filii Augustinus, De Trinitate, V
Quarto, in divinis est numerus. Antecedens patet quia Trinitas. Et consequentia patet quia in quolibet numero dualitas sequitur unitatem et unitas praecedit eam.

Quinto, quidquid est primo propinquius illud videtur prius sed Filius est propinquior. Primo quia immediatior Patri, igitur Filius est prior Spiritu Sancto et pari passu Pater Filio. Maior nota et minor probatur quia Spiritus Sanctus procedit a Patre mediantem Filio.

Pro solutione rationum contra primam conclusionem, notandum quod mensura dicitur multipliciter. Uno modo per ipsius mensurae replicationem, et sic sumitur
X Metaphysicae Aristoteles, Metaphysicae, X, xxx
de ponderibus.
Secundo modo per assimulationem et approximationem aliorum ad ipsum et imitationem.

Tertio sumitur secundum causalitatem prioritatem et determinationem et sic dicitur ars mensura artificienti[?], sic dicitur
V Metaphysicae Aristoteles, Metaphysicase, V, xxx
de intelligibili.
Quarto modo secundum formalem reformationem seu receptationem et sic scientia dicitur mensura scitorum.
Quinto modo per situs interpositionem et altitudo istius situs est mensura tantae vel tantae distantiae.
Primo et ultimo modis, Deus non dicitur mensura, licet bene secundo, tertio, et quarto modis est mensura rerum.

Ad primum, dico quod sumendo genus large pro quocumque communi verificante de pluribus sive univoce vel aequivoce, sic potest concedi Deum esse eiusdem generis cum creaturis, quia isto modo ens dicitur de creaturis et Deo. Si vero genus sumatur stricte et proprie pro aliquo quod dicitur de pluribus univoce, tantum sic conceditur antecedens et negatur consequentia. Primo pro illo sensu sed in alio non.

Ad secundum, dicitur quod licet inter Deum et creaturas non sit proportio quantitative adaequationis, tamen inter ea est proportio ordinis seu exemplaris imitationis et hoc sufficit ad hoc quod sit rerum mensura.
Ad tertium, negatur consequentia et ad probationem dicitur quod replicatio nota est de ratione mensurae simpliciter, sed tantum mensurae quantitativae.
Ad quartum, negatur consequentia, quia, licet nomen quantitatis fuerit in potentiam rebus quantitatis primo et proprie, tamen cum hoc stat quod significatum possit Deo competere.

Ad primum contra secundam conclusionem, conceditur consequens, sed tamen non est aeternum facere loquendo de facere Dei ad extra. Posset etiam dici quod nota omne velle Dei est facere, licet
non
econverso.

Ad secundum, negatur consequentia ad probationem, dico quod Christum pati potest dupliciter summi. Uno modo pro dicto seu pro hac propositione Christus patitur. Secundo modo pro re dicti scilicet pro instanti pro quo Christus patiebatur et passione Christi. Si primo modo sumitur non probatur consequentia, quia illae propositiones non aeternaliter fuerit. Si secundo modo tunc dicitur quod Deus vult quidquid unquam voluit et omnem volitum est praesens in suo praesenti instanti aeternitatis ubi nullus est fluxus praeteriti vel futuri. Et per illam solutionem possunt solvi plura argumenta similia in hac materia.
Ad tertium, negatur consequentia quia talis necessitatis temporis praeteriti non provenit ex intrinseco notitiae divinae, sed potius ab extrinseceo. Puta quia res posita est inesse actuali.
Ad quartum, negatur minor quia tam simplex et tam simplex et tam indivisibiliter est aeternitas quam simplex vel indivisibile est signum vel instans aeternitatis et econverso.

Ad quintum de Spiritu Sancto hic respondet Augustinus homelia 45 super Iohannem ostendens quod vere dicimus de Deo fuit et erit quia numquam de eo deerit numquam defuit non quiddam quod aliqua signorum pluralitas in ipso sit.

Aliter potest dici quod Deus, licet proprie non sit in tempore et personae quia non variatur secundum tempus per accidens tamen est in tempore quia est quando tempus est ideo verba praeteriti et futuri temporis de deo dici possunt haec responsio trahitur ex dictis
aegidi libro primo, distinctione hac, parte 3a, quaestione 4a. Aegidius Romanos, I, d. 9, p. 3, q. 4
Tertio potest dici quod li antequam mundus fieret potest se habere habitualiter hoc est si fuisset tempus ante mundum habuisset claritatem in illo.

Quarto, posset dici quod, si recipitur tempus pro quacumque imaginaria successione possibili positiva vel privativa, tunc infinitum tempus fuit ante mundum quia talia possunt capi pro talibus signis illius imaginarii successus.

Ad boetium dicentem quod nunc stans etc conceditur quantum ad nostrae mentis apprehensionem sive quantum ad nostri intellectus cogitationem Ad augustini dicitur quod loquitur de aeternitate participata et secundum quid non autem de aeternitate simpliciter seu loquitur de aeternitate a parte post.

Ad primum contra 3am
conclusionem dicitur quod licet verbum divinum sit immensum mensura ab eo distincta, tamen dicitur mensum mensura quae est sua aeternitas prout ostendit
Aegidius distinctione 8 primi, parte 3a, quaestione 3a. Aegidius Romanos, I, d. 8, p. 3, q. 3

Ad illud
Exodi 3 Exodus 3:XXX
dicitur quod sumitur aeternitas dicitur uno modo primo per pro peryodo[?] unius cuiusque vitae naturalis, secundo modo pro uniformi et immobili simultanea existentia. Primo modo conceditur simpliciter, sed secundo modo negatur. Secundo posset dici secundum
Anselmum Prosologion capitulo tertio Anselmus, Prosologion, 3 (I, 103).
quod Deus est ultra illa quae etiam finem non habebunt tum quia illa nullatenus sine eo esse possunt ipse autem non minus esse si omnia in nihilum irent tum secundo quia illa possunt cogitari habere finem Deus vero nequaquam cum etiam quia Dei et eorum aeternitas est Deo tota sed eis non.

Ad tertium primo negatur consequentia quia similiter posset argui quod essentia haberet principium quia ipsa est idem filio Item posset dici quod si summatur principium pro durationis sic filius et spiritus sanctus habent principium quia sicut pater communicat filio deitatem ita et aeternitatem si aut sumatur pro durationis limitatione sic nulla persona divina habet principium
Ad quartum de numero dicitur quod sicut in divinis est sapientia magnitudo tamen non qualitas aut quantitas sic est ibi ternarius non tamen proprie dictus numeris et de hoc videbitur infra.

Ad quintum negatur minor quia non ideo dicitur quod pater producit spiritum sanctum mediante filio quia pater non immediate producit ipsum sed quia filius habet a patre virtutem spiratiam sed contra hoc obicitur per Augustinum libro de triplici habita?lo[?] ubi dicit iusti in patria videbunt quid inter est inter generationem et spirationem et videbunt quod pater praecedit filium non natura sed origine

Ad hoc tamen dicit Alphonsus quod Augustinus vult dicere quod inter Patrem et Filium est prioritas originis non in quo, sed aliquo, id est quod Filius ordine naturae est a Patre, non tamen est ibi prioritas signorum realis d?va[?] et mensurativa ut Scotus et sequaces sui intuntur[?] probare, quorum rationes solvit Alphonsus in hac distinctione nona vide ibi.

div.head: Conclusiones pro distinctione nona
div.p:
Nunc ad distinctionem personarum. Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 9, c. 1 [n.1], (I, 103, ll. 6).
Haec distinctio continet nona conclusiones. Prima quod Pater, et Filius, et Spiritus Sanctus sunt unus Deus, natura tamen Pater non est Filius nec Filius est Pater nec Spiritus Sanctus est Pater vel Filius.

Secunda conclusio: una essentia est Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti in qua non est aliud Pater, aliud Filius, aliud Spiritus Sanctus, licet personaliter alius sit Pater, alius Filius, alius Spiritus Sanctus.
Tertia conclusio: licet Filius sit genitus a Patre, tamen Pater non fuit antequam Filius, sed omnes illae tres personae sunt sibi coaeternae et coaequales.
Quattuor conclusio: sicut splendor qui gignitur ab igne coaeternus est igni seu esset coaeternus sic Filius est Patri.

Quinta conclusio: cum Patrem dicimus vel nominamus Filium designativus, quia nemo sibi ipsi est Pater cum vero Filium nominamus etiam Patrem fatemur, quia nemo sibi ipsi Filius est ex quo sequitur quod nec Filius sine Patre nec Pater sine Filio esset potest semper, ergo Pater semper et Filius.
Sexta conclusio: quod Filii Dei generatio est ineffabilis quia non plene exemplificari vel intelligi potest a quocumque moralium, licet aliquid de ipsa potest intelligi et dici.
Septima conclusio: licet possit concedit quod Filius semper nascitur de Patre, tamen congruentius dicitur semper natus.
Octava conclusio: quod confitemur natum unigenitum Deum ante tempus nec ante esse quam natum nec ante natum quam esse et sic de ista distinctione.
